## Basis for Choice Modeling {.smaller}
- Aggregate demand models (such as those we have been discussing) based on observations for **groups of travelers** or **average relations** for zones
- **Discrete choice:** probability an individual chooses a given option a function of their socioeconomic characteristics & relative attractiveness of the option
- Cannot estimate via least squares because probability is unobserved â€“ only observe choice
- Models are **probabilistic** & do not give an outcome value such as **trips** â€“ must use probability concepts to generate discrete outcomes (summation over all observations to give expected number choosing option or use sample enumeration to allocate discrete outcomes)

## Properties of Discrete Choice (DC)
- Based on theories of **individual behavior** & do not constitute physical analogies â€“ therefore stable over time & space
- Can be more **statistically efficient** than aggregate models because each observation is an outcome rather than using aggregations of potentially hundreds of observations
- DM less likely to suffer from bias due to correlation between aggregate units â€“ i.e., **ecological correlation** (fallacy)

## Theoretical Framework {.smaller}
- Individuals belong to a **homogeneous population** $I$, act rationally, & **possess perfect information** â€“ i.e., they always select the option that maximizes their net personal utility subject to legal, social, physical, &/or budgetary (both time & money) constraints
- There is a certain set $ğ´ = \{ğ´_1, â€¦ğ´_ğ‘—,â€¦ğ´_J\}$ of available alternatives & a set X of vectors of measured attributes of individuals & their alternatives
- An individual $i$ is endowed with a set of attributes $ğ‘¥ \in ğ‘‹$ & faces a choice set $ğ´(i) \in ğ´$
- We will assume choice set is predetermined for individuals

## Theoretical Framework
- Modeler, an observer, does not **posses complete information** about all elements considered by the individual making choice
- Modeler assumes $ğ‘ˆ_{ij}$  can be represented by two components:
  - A **measurable**, **systematic**, or **representative** part $ğ‘‰_{ij}$,  which is a function of the measured attributes $x$
  - A random part $\epsilon_{ij}$,  which reflects **indiosyncratic** & **taste variation**, together with measurement or observational errors made by the modeler

## Theoretical Framework
- Modeler sets utility $ğ‘ˆ_{ij}}=ğ‘‰_{ij}+\epsilon_{ij}}$ to address two apparent irrationalities
  1. That two individuals faced with the **same situation** & having the **same personal attributes** make different choices
  2. That an individual may not select the alternative that **appears** to be the *best one*
- Often assumed $V_{ij}$ given by $\sum_k^K \beta_{jk} x_{ijk}$ here $\beta_{jk}$ are assumed **constant** for all individuals $I$ in the homogeneous set but **may vary across alternatives** $J$

## Theoretical Framework {.smaller}
- Individual chooses an alternative based on $ğ‘ˆ_{ij}â‰¥ ğ‘ˆ_{qj} \forall A_q \in A(i)$
- Or: $ğ‘‰_{ij}  â€“ ğ‘‰_{iq}â‰¥\epsilon_{iq}  âˆ’ \epsilon_{ij}$ (notice swapping of ğ’‹ & q)

Not possible to know with certainty if the inequality holds, so use 
$$ğ‘ƒ_{ij}  = ğ‘ƒ(\epsilon{ij} \leq \epsilon_{iq} + (V_{ij} - V_{iq})) \forall A_q \in A(i)$$ 
- Do not know distribution of joint residuals, so cannot derive analytical expression for model
- Can denote $f(\epsilon) = f(\epsilon_1, \epsilon_2, ... \epsilon_J$ & know they are **random variables** with a certain distribution

## Theoretical Framework {.smaller}
- Can note that distribution for $f(U)$ is the same but with mean $V$ rather than 0
$$P_{ij} = \int_{R_J} f(\epsilon) d\epsilon$$
$$\text{where } R_J = \begin{cases}
\epsilon_{iq} \leq \epsilon_{ij} + (V_{ij} - V_{iq}), & \forall A_q \in A(i) \\
V_{ij}) + \epsilon_{ij} \ge 0 \\
\end{cases}$$
- Assuming independent & identically distributed (**IID**) residuals,
$$f(\epsilon_1,...\epsilon_J) = \prod_j^J g(\epsilon_j)$$
- And (drop $i$ for simplicity)
$$P_j = \int_{-\infty}^\infty g(\epsilon_j) d\epsilon_j \prod_{q \neq j} \int_{-\infty}^{V_j-V_q+\epsilon_j} g(\epsilon_q) d\epsilon_q$$

## Generating the Logit Model {.smaller}
- Assuming IID Gumbel (**Extreme Value Type I**) residuals, or equivalently that residual differences are **logistically distributed**, gives the standard multinomial logit specification
- Termed *softmax function* in machine learning field
$$P_{ij} = \frac{exp(\mu V_{ij})}{\sum_{A_q \in A(i)} exp(\mu V_{iq})}$$
- Where $\mu$ is a **scale parameter** assumed equal to 1.0 for identification

## Direct & Cross Elasticity
- **Direct elasticity:** direct effect of changing a variable value related to a good on demand for the same good
  - E.g., elasticity of transit demand wrt transit fare, transit travel time, or transit headway
- **Cross elasticity:** effect of changing a variable value related to a good on demand for a different good
  - E.g., elasticity of transit demand wrt auto travel time

## Logit -  Direct Elasticity
Direct elasticity of the probability of an individual $i$ choosing alternative $j$ wrt a change in an attribute/independent variable $X_{jk}$ with coefficient $\beta_k$ (ignoring $i$ subscripts for simplicity)

$$e_{direct} = \frac{\partial P_j}{\partial X_{jk}} \frac{X_{jk}}{P_j}=(1-P_j)X_{jk}\beta_k$$


## Logit -  Cross Elasticity {.smaller}
- Cross elasticity of the probability of an individual $i$ choosing alternative $j$ wrt a change in an attribute/independent variable $X_{lk}$ with coefficient $\beta_k$ for a different alternative

$$e_{cross} = -P_jX_{jk}\beta_k$$

- Above is same regardless of alternative $l$. I.e., **all alternatives** $J$ have the same cross-elasticity wrt an attribute $k$ of alternative $j$
- Above results from independence of irrelevant alternatives (**IIA**) property of basic logit model

## Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives (IIA) Property
Consider we have two modes: auto (a) & bus (b)

$$\frac{P_a}{P_b} = \frac{exp(V_a)}{exp(V_b)} = exp(V_a - V_b)$$
I.e., the relative probability of choosing auto vs. bus depends **only** on the utilities of the two alternatives

- Now what if our buses are **red (rb)** & we paint half **blue (bb)**?

## IIA Contâ€¦
- If the IIA assumption does not hold, we can make other error distribution assumptions
  -   Nested logit (can handle complex decision structures)
  - Probit (normal error terms, very general model, but can be difficult to work with it)
